title: Quiz 2: Application, Materials & Removal
description: Evaluate your skills in cast application, padding techniques, material selection, and safe removal.

questions.question: Arrange the steps of cast application in the correct order:
questions.explanation: Protection first (Stockinette), then Padding, then the rigid Material, Molding while wet, and finally Trimming.
questions.hint: Protect the skin before applying the hard shell.

questions.question: Which rule of immobilization is generally followed for fractures?

options.text: Immobilize one joint above and one joint below the fracture
Immobilize the entire limb regardless of fracture
Immobilize the joint proximal to the fracture only

questions.explanation: The standard rule is to immobilize the joint above and the joint below the fracture to prevent movement transmitted through muscle attachments.
questions.hint: Think about stability above and below.

questions.question: You should use your fingertips to mold the plaster cast to ensure a tight fit.
questions.explanation: Molding should be done with the PALMS of the hands. Fingertips cause indentations which can lead to pressure sores.

questions.question: Select the correct recommended widths for plaster bandages for different body parts:

richContent.content:
Body PartSize
Thigh?
Leg?
Forearm?

questions.explanation: Standard sizes: Thigh (8 inch), Leg (6 inch), Forearm (4 inch).

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'Stockinette'?

options.text: To protect the skin from the casting material
To make the cast set faster

questions.explanation: Stockinette is the first layer applied to protect the skin from the rough casting material.
questions.hint: It goes on the skin first.

questions.question: When removing a cast with Plaster Shears, the blade should be kept:
questions.explanation: The shear blade must be parallel to the skin to avoid cutting or pinching the patient.
questions.hint: Think about safety and preventing cuts.

questions.question: What is the name of the tool used to remove a well-padded cast by vibration/oscillation?
questions.explanation: The Electric Plaster Cutter (or Cast Saw) oscillates to cut the rigid material without cutting soft tissue (if used correctly).

questions.question: Match the padding material with its description:

pairs.right: Synthetic mesh applied directly to skin
Used for extra padding over bony prominences

questions.explanation: Stockinette is the liner; Webril is the rolled padding; Felt is often used for spot padding.

questions.question: Why is an electric plaster cutter unsafe to use in the presence of oxygen?

options.text: It produces sparks which can ignite inflammable gases

questions.explanation: The motor can produce sparks, creating a fire hazard in oxygen-rich environments.

questions.question: Select the features of Synthetic (Fiberglass) casts compared to Plaster of Paris:
questions.explanation: Synthetic casts are light, strong, waterproof, and radiolucent, but are more expensive and harder to mold than POP.

questions.question: A good rule of thumb for heat generation is that heat is ___BLANK___ proportional to the setting time.
questions.explanation: Heat is inversely proportional to setting time (faster setting = more heat) and directly proportional to layers.

questions.question: You should use hot water to dip plaster bandages to make them dry instantly.
questions.explanation: Hot water accelerates setting excessively, risking burns to the patient and making the cast brittle or difficult to mold.

questions.question: What is the best method for drying a cast?

options.text: Heat lamp close to the cast

questions.explanation: Natural drying prevents uneven drying and burning. Artificial heat is generally discouraged.

questions.question: Which complication can arise from a cast that is too loose?
questions.explanation: If a cast is too loose (e.g., after swelling subsides), it cannot hold the bone fragments in place, leading to loss of position.
questions.hint: If it's not tight enough, things move.

questions.question: Order the steps for removing a cast with shears:

items.text: Draw a guideline avoiding bony prominences
Insert shear between cast and padding
Clear the cutting area every 4-6 cuts

questions.explanation: Plan (mark), Insert, Cut safely, Clear debris.
